sp.p: By heaven, Libanus, I do entreat you, be pleased by your deeds to come to your master's rescue; do give me those twenty minæ: you see that thus in love I stand in need of them.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: It shall be seen to; I wish it done; return here at nightfall. Now bid her, ever so little, to beg and entreat them of me.

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: to LIBANUS. Do you wish me to begin with caressing, or with kissing you?

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Why, really, with them both.

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: And do you then, I do entreat you, prove the saving of us both.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: O Libanus, my patron, do give me that; 'tis more becoming for the freed-manFor the freed-man: By "libertus," or "freed-man," he means himself, while Libanus is his "patronus," or "patron.", than for the patron, to be carrying a burden in the street.

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: My Libanus, golden apple of my eye, the gift and the very grace of love; there's a dear, whatever you wish, I'll do; prithee, do give us that money.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Call me, then, your little duck, dove, or your puppet; your swallow, jackdaw, little sparrow, your mannikin: make of me the reptile that crawls, so that I may have a double tongueA double tongue: An unseemly allusion s intended in this expression.; enfold me in your arms, and embrace my neck.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: She, embrace you, villain?

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Really, how undeserving I do seem. You shan't for no purpose have uttered a speech so unseemly against me. By my troth, if indeed you expect to get this money, this day you shall carry myself on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: What? I, carry you?

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Otherwise, you shan't get this money from me.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Heavens, I'm undone! Still, if indeed it is decorous for the master to carry the servant, mount.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: In this way are proud people wont to be tamed. Stand still then, just as you were wont to do when formerly a boyWhen formerly a boy: "Honi soit qui mal y pense" should be said to Lambinus and the other Commentators who have imagined an indelicate allusion to be couched under these words. He clearly alludes to the boyish game of leapfrog, at which they had in childhood been accustomed "to make a back.". Do you understand what I say? He prepares to get upon the shoulders of ARGYRIPPUS. Aye--so--move on: I praise you much; not any horse is there more clever than yourself as a horse.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: while stooping. Get on, directly. LIB. I'll do so. He gets on. Hallo!--what's the matter? How are you going? By my troth, I'll deprive you of your barley then, if you don't ambleIf you don't amble: "Badizas." This is an adaptation of the Greek verb badi/zw, "to go.", lifting up your feet.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Prithee, Libanus, there's enough now.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Never this day, by my troth, shall you get anything by entreaty. For now up hill with the spur will I push on my steed. After that, I'll deliver you to the millers, that there you may be tortured as you runTortured as you run: He alludes to the occupation of asses and worn-out horses in grinding at the corn-mill.. Stand still, that I may now at once get down for the hill, although you are but a bad one. Gets off his shoulders.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Well now--since you've both made fun of me just as you liked, are you going to give the money?

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Why, yes, if, indeed, you erect to me a statue and an altar, and then sacrifice an ox to me here as though to a God; for I am the Divinity Salvation to you.

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: Nay, but, master, do you betake yourself away from him, and do you come to me. And, what he has demanded for himself, will you erect a statue for me, and offer prayers to me?

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: But what Divinity am I to call you?

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: Fortune, and that the Propitious oneAnd that the Propitious one: "Fortuna Cbsequens" or "Propitious Fortune," had a Temple at Rome..

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: You are better than he then.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Why, is there ever anything better for a man than Salvation?

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Though I praise Fortune, still, not to speak in dispraise of the Divinity Salvation----

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: By the powers, but they are good, both of them.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: I shall know it, when they have conferred anything that's good.

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: Wish for that which you desire to befall you.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: What if I do wish it?

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: It shall come to pass.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: I wish for her to be devoted to me alone this whole year round.

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: You have obtained it.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Do you really say so?

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: I do say so for certain.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: Come to me, in my turn, and make trial: wish ardently for that which you especially desire to happen to you; it shall be done.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: What other thing could I ardently wish for rather than that of which I am in want? Oblige me with twenty silver minæ to give to her mother.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: They shall be given: take care and be of good courage, your wishes shall be fulfilled.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Just as they are wont, Salvation and Fortune are deceiving mortals.

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: I this day have been the head in finding this money for you.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: I have been the foot.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Why, neither head nor foot of your talking is visible; I can understand neither what you mean, nor why you are trifling with me.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: I think that now you've been teased enough; now let's disclose the matter as it really stands. Give your attention, Argyrippus, if you please. Your father has ordered us to bring this money to you.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: How very à propos and opportunely you have brought it.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: giving him the bag. Here, in this, there will be twenty good minæ, obtained by bad means: these, on certain conditions, he bade us give you.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Prithee, what are they?

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: That you would grant him her favours and an entertainment.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Bid him come, I beg. For him who deserves it right well, we'll do what he wishes, him who has brought these scattered loves of ours to a happy result.

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: You'll permit your father then, Argyrippus, to caress her?

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: She, by being restored to me, will easily cause me to permit it. Prithee, Leonida, run, and beg my father to come here.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: He has been in the house some time.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: He hasn't come this way, at all events.

sp.speaker: LIBANUS
sp.p: pointing to the back way. He came round that wayCame round that way: Well he might! by the lane, through the garden, lest any one of his friends should see him coming here; he's afraid that his wife may come to know of it. If your mother knew about the money, how it was obtained----

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Well, well--do use words of good omensUse words of good omen: "Benedicite." This was a form made use of for the purpose of averting bad omens.; go in-doors quickly, farewell.

sp.speaker: LEONIDA
sp.p: And you two, love on. He and LIBANUS go into the house of DEMÆNETUS; ARGYRIPPUS and PHILENIUM into that of CLEÆRETA.

div1.stage: Enter DIABOLUS and a PARASITE, with a scroll in his hand.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Come now, show me this agreement that you've written out between myself and the procuress. Read over the conditions; for you are a quite unique composerA quite unique composer: "Poeta" is here used in the primary sense of the word, from the Greek poihth\s, "a maker," "artist," or "contriver." in such matters.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: I'll make the procuress be terrified when she hears the conditions.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, proceed and read them over to me.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Are you attending?

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: I'm all attention.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: reads the agreement. "Diabolus, the son of Glaucus, has made a present to Cleæreta, the procuress, of twenty silver minæ, that Philenium may be with him night and day for this whole year."

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Yes, and not with any other person.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Am I to add that?

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Add it, and take care and write it plainly and distinctly.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: writes it down, and then reads. "And not admit any other man whatever, because either her friend or her patron, she may choose to call him----"

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Not any one!

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: "Or because she may say that he is the lover of a female friend of hers. The door must be closed to all men except to yourself. On the door she must write that she is engaged. Or, because she may affirm that the letter has been brought from abroad, there is not to be even any letter in the house, nor so much as a waxed tablet; and if there is any useless pictureAny useless picture: Some of the Commentators have supposed that indecent or immodest pictures are here meant. Such is not the fact. Portraits were taken among the Romans in profile, in wax, which was laid on a plane surface; and probably other pictures were similarly constructed. In his jealousy, Diabolus will not allow Philenium to keep any useless or valueless picture, for fear lest she may melt it, to use the wax for tablets, as a medium of correspondence with a paramour. To a portrait of this kind, Laodamia probably refers in her Epistle to Protesilaüs, in the Heroides of Ovid, l. 133: "But while as a warrior thou shalt be wielding arms in a distant region, I have a waxen figure which represents thy features.", let her sell it; if she does not part with it, within four days from the time when she has received the money of you, let it be considered as your own; you to burn it if you like; so that she may have no wax, with which she may be able to make a letter. She is to invite no guest; you are to invite them. On no one of them is she to cast her eyes: if she looks upon any other person, she must be blind forthwithMust be blind forthwith: This is probably a polite way of saying, "Let her leave the room forthwith.". Then she is to drink cup by cup equally with yourself. She is to receive it from you; she is to hand it to you for you to drink. She is not to have a relish for less or for more than yourself."

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: That's quite to my taste.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: reading. "She is to remove all causes of suspicion from her, nor is she to tread on any man's footTread on any man's foot: From passages in Ovid's Amours and Art of Love, we learn that this was a favourite method of communication by intriguing parties. with her foot; when she rises she is neither to step upon the next couch, nor when she gets down from the couch is she thence to extend her hand to any one; she is not to give to nor ask of any one a ring for her to look at; she is not to present dice to any man whatever except to yourself; when she throwsWhen she throws: When throwing the dice, it was the custom to invoke some favourite object, which was thought to bring good luck to the thrower. See the Notes to the Captivi, Act I., Sc. 1. She is not to say, "You I invoke," lest, by the ambiguity, it should be intended to apply to another man and not to her protector them, she is not to say, You I call upon,' she is to mention your name. She may call on any Goddess that she pleases as propitious to her, but on no God: if she should chance to be very full of devotion, she is to tell you, and you are to pray to him that he may be propitious. She is neither to nod at any man, wink, or make a sign. In fine, if the lamp goes out, she is not to move a single joint of herself in the dark."

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: That's very good; so, in fact, she must do: but expunge that about the chamber; for my part, I prefer that she should move. I don't wish her to have an excuse, and to say that it is forbidden her by her vow.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: I understand, you fear some quibble.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Then as you bid me, I'll strike it out. Erases it.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: And why not?

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Hear the rest.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Say on, I'm listening.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: goes on reading. "And she is not to use any shuffling words, nor is she to know how to speak in any tongue but the Attic. If perchance she should begin to cough, she is not to cough so as to expose her tongue to any one in coughing. But if she should pretend as though she had a running at the noseA running at the nose: The meaning seems to be, that if her nose runs by reason of a catarrh, she is not to open her mouth to put her tongue out, but that Diabolus is, in common parlance, to wipe her nose for her., even then she is not to do so; you yourself must wipe her lips rather than that she should open her mouth before another person. And her mother, the procuress, is not to come in in the middle of the wine, nor is she to utter a word of abuse to any one; if she does so speak, let this be her fine, to go for twenty days without wine."

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: You have written it nicely; a clever agreement.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: "Then, if she bids her maid-servant carry chaplets, garlands, or unguents, to Venus or to Cupid, your servant is to watch whether she gives them to Venus or to a man. If perchance she should say she wishes to keep herself in purityKeep herself in purity: He probably alludes to the festival of Isis or Ceres, on which occasion it was usual for the female votaries rigidly to separate themselves from the society of men. The translation of the next line is somewhat modified., let her account for as many nights as she has kept herself in purity. These are no trifles; for they are no funeral dirgeNo funeral dirge: "Mortualia" were the songs which hired female mourners sang at funerals; and which, as being especially worthless, were pre-eminently called "nugæ," or "trifles."."

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: The conditions please me entirely; follow me indoors.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: I follow. (They go into the house of CLEÆRETA.)

div1.stage: Enter DIABOLUS and the PARASITE.One scene, at least, is clearly lost here, as we are not informed how Diabolus has become acquainted with the manœuvres to obtain the money, and the disgraceful compact made by Demænetus; although, not improbably, he has caught sight of him in the house of the procuress.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Follow this way. Am I to put up with this, or shall I hold my tongue? I would rather die than not discover this to his wife. And say you so, old man? With a mistress would you be acting the part of a youngster? Would you be excusing yourself to your wife, and calling yourself an aged man? Would you be taking the mistress from her lover? And would you be presenting the money to the procuress, and be secretly pilfering it from your wife at home? You should hang me, rather than you should carry off these matters undiscovered. On my honor, I'll really go this instant hence to her whom I'm sure that you'll very soon be destroying, in order that you may be able to supply your extravagance, unless, indeed, she shall first prevent you.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: I'm of opinion that thus you must act. 'Tis more becoming that I should disclose this matter, rather than yourself, lest she may think that you, excited by reason of love, rather than for her own sake, have acted thus.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: Why, faith, you say what's right. Do you then contrive to raise a storm and strife against him, that he, together with his own son, is carousing with one mistress the livelong day, and that he's secretly pilfering from her.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Don't suggest to me. I'll take care of that.

sp.speaker: DIABOLUS
sp.p: But I'll wait for you at home. Exit DIABOLUS; the PARASITE goes into the house of DEMÆNETUS.

div1.stage: A Table, and everything requisite for an Entertainment, being placed before the house of CLEÆRETA, enter ARGYRIPPUS, DEMÆNETUS, and PHILENIUM, from the house of CLEÆRETA.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Come then, father, let's take our places, please.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: As you bid me, my son, so it shall be.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: . to the ATTENDANTS. Lads, spread the table.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Is it at all displeasing to you, son, if she takes her place by me? They take their places.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Duty, father, keeps sorrow from my eyes; although I love her, still I can control my feelings, not to take it to heart because she takes her place by you.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: It becomes a young man to be respectful, Argyrippus.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Troth, father, through proper regard for you, I can be so.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Come, then, let's enjoy this banquet with wine and pleasant discourse. I don't wish to be feared, I prefer myself to be loved by you, my son.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: In truth, I do them both, as is proper for a son.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I'd believe it, if I saw you were cheerful.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Why, do you think that I'm sorrowful?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Do I think so? You, whom I see as melancholy as if the dayAs if the day: He probably means the day for coming up for judgment, or else for trial. of trial had been named for you.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Don't you say that.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Don't you be so, then I'll not say so.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Well then, look at me; I'm laughing. He affects to laugh.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I'd like that those who wish me ill would laugh thus.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: I know, indeed, father, why you now suppose to yourself that I'm sad; it is because she is by you. And really, father, by my faith, to tell you the truth, that matter does hurt me; and not for this reason, that I don't desire for you that which you wish, but because I love her; another woman, indeed, I could easily endure to be by you.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: But I have a fancy for this one.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Then you have what you desire; for myself, I wish for what I could desire.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Submit to it this one day, since I've given you the power to be with her for a year, and have procured for you the command of money in your amour.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Well, by doing that, you have laid me under an obligation to you.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Why then don't you show yourself cheerful to me? They commence the banquet, PHILENIUM reclining below DEMÆNETUS.

div1.stage: Enter ARTEMONA and the PARASITE, from the house of DEMÆNETUS, at the further side of the stage.In the early part of this Scene, the wife and the Parasite do not see Demænetus, who is carousing in the front of Cleæreta's house, at the other side of the stage. We must remember that the Roman stage was of vast extent--as much, according to some writers, as 180 feet in width. Perhaps a wall extended a little forward by the side of the house, which would preclude the view of what was going on behind it and near to the door until Artemona and the Parasite had traversed the stage.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Prithee, do you say that my husband is carousing here, together with my son?--and that he has carried to his mistress twenty minæ of silver?--and that, with the knowledge of my son, his father is perpetrating this wickedness?

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Trust me in nothing henceforth, either divine or human, Artemona, if you find me untruthful in this matter.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Wretched then am I, who have supposed that, beyond others, my husband was sober, decent, chaste, and especially fond of his wife.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: But now, henceforth, understand that he, before all men, is a person of the smallest worth--a drunkard, a good-for-nothing fellow, unchaste, and a contemner of his own wife.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: I' faith, if this wasn't true, he would never be doing the things that he is now doing.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Upon my word, I too always hitherto took him to be a decent person; but by this action he declares himself,--to be carousing, indeed, together with his son, and, a decrepit old man, toying with a mistress in his company.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: For this it is, i' faith, that he's going out to dinner every day. He says that he's going to Archidemus, Chereas, Chærestratus, Clinius, Chremes, Cratinus, Dinias, Demosthenes: while he's thinking of debauchery, and public dens of infamy with his harlot.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Why don't you bid your maid-servants carry him off home upon their shoulders?

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Do you only be quiet. By my troth, I'll surely give him some trouble.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: I'm sure of it, that so it will befall him, so long, indeed, as you shall continue married to him.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: I was fancying that this fellow was still giving attendance either in the senate or to his dependants: that for that reason it was, that, worn out with fatigue, he snored the whole night through. Wearied with his labours out of doors he comes home at night. Another's farm he ploughs, his own he leaves untilled. Both he himself is corrupted, and he corrupts his son as well.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Do you only follow me this way, I'll make you just now to fall upon the man himself in the very fact.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: By heaven, there's nothing that I could more wish for.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Just stop there. He moves stealthily forward, and examines the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: returning to her. If perchance you were to see your husband reclining, if you beheld him with a garland on, caressing a mistress, could you recognize him?

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: I' troth, I could.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: points to the other end of the stage. Then there's your man.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: moving stealthily forward with the PARASITE. I'm undone.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Stay a little. Let's observe in private, from ambush, what business they are about.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: What end will you put to your caresses, father?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I confess, my son----

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: What do you confess?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: That I'm utterly undone with love for her.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: to ARTEMONA. Do you hear what he says?

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: I hear.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: to PHILENIUM. Ought I not to filch the mantle from my wife at home, which she is so fond of, and bring it to you? Though my wife's life should last a whole year in consequence, by my troth I could not be dissuaded from doing so.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: to ARTEMONA. Do you suppose that he has been accustomed to frequent a brothel to-day for the first time?

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Upon my faith, it was he that was pilfering me; whereas I was suspecting my maid-servants, and was tormenting the wretched creatures who were innocent all the while.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Father, bid him pour out some wine; 'tis a long time since I drank firstSince I drank first: They probably took the first draught each in his turn. Argyrippus tells his father that he is dry, and that it is a long time since he had the first draught..

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: to the SERVANT. Begin, boy, from the topFrom the top: We are to suppose that the three are reclining or one "triclinium," or couch. Argyrippus lies at the top, his father below him, and Philenium the lowest, with her head reclining on the old man's breast.. To PHILENIUM. Come, do you meanwhile from below give me a kiss. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: to the PARASITE. Wretch that I am, I'm undone! How the villain, the garnishing of a bierOf a bier: "Capulus" was another name of the "lectica" or "feretrum," on which the corpse was carried to the funeral pile. In the case of rich people, the "capuli" were sometimes made of ivory, and covered with gold and purple., is kissing away.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: A breath, by my faith, somewhat sweeter than that of my wife.

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: Tell me, there's a dear, does the breath of your wife smell bad?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I'd prefer to drink bilge-water, if it were necessary, rather than kiss her.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: apart. By heavens, you are a wretch. PAR. apart. I' faith, he's deserving so to be.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: How say you, father? Takes a draught in the meanwhile.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: apart. Aye, pray, how say you? By my troth, to your own great detriment, you've surely said that against me. Never mind; only de you come home, I'll let you know what danger there is in speaking abusively against a wife with a dowry.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Don't you love my mother?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Who--I? I love her just now, because she isn't present.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: How, when she is present?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Then, I wish she was dead.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: apart to ARTEMONA. This fellow is fond of you, according to what he says.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: On my word, he's surely laying out all this at interest; for if, this day, he returns home, I'll especially have my revenge in kissing him.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: handing the dice-box. Father, throw the dice; that afterwards I may have a throw.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: By all means. You, Philenium, for myself, and death for my wife. He throws. 'Tis Venus's castVenus's, cast: "Venereus jactus" was the best throw on the set of four "tali," or knuckle-bone dice, used by the ancients. It is supposed to have been a combination of the numbers, the sum of which was fourteen. When trying to throw the "Venereus jactus," it was usual to mention the name of the mistress of the thrower; and Demænetus> throws in "death to his wife," by way of supplement. From the next line, he appears to have been successful in his throw.. Lads, clap your hands, and give me some honeyed wine in my cup, in honor of my throw.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: apart. I can hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: apart. If you haven't learned the fulling tradeHaven't learned the fulling trade: He intends a pun here upon the word "durare," which meant either "to endure," "bear," or "hold out;" as also "to full," "harden," or "thicken cloth," by the fuller's art. Artemona says that she cannot "durare" in the first sense; on which the Parasite quibbles, and says, "Because you have not learnt the fulling art." In the next line also a ploy upon words is intended, as "invadi in oculos" may mean either "present yourself before his eyes" or "attack his eyes," and claw them out. No doubt the Parasite would have relished the fun, if she had taken his advice in the latter sense., it's not to be wondered at; now it's quite fitting for you to beset his eyes. They make their appearance before the revellers.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: By heavens, I will live, and you this day have made that invocation to your own great misfortune.

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: Will some one run to fetch the undertakersThe undertaker: The "pollinctores" were slaves, who belonged to the "libitinarii," or "undertakers," and whose duty it was to anoint the body with oil and perfumes before it was burnt.?

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Health to you, mother.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Health indeed after this fashion!

sp.speaker: A PARASITE
sp.p: aside. Demænetus is dead. 'Tis time to betake myself hence: this battle bravely waxes hot. I'll be off to Diabolus. I'll tell him his orders are performed as he desired them; and in the meantime I'll persuade him that we should take a meal, while these people are squabbling. Afterwards, in fine, I'll bring him here to-morrow, to the procuress, that he may give her the twenty mince, that, in his turn, he in his passion may be enabled to obtain this damsel. I hope that Argyrippus will be able to be prevailed upon to allow him to pass each alternate night with him in her company; for, unless I obtain that, I've lost my patronMy patron: "Regem." Literally, "my king;" the name which Parasites bestowed upon their patrons.; so great is the passion of the man by reason of his love. He quietly withdraws.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: addressing PHILENIUM. What business have you to give a retreat here in your house to my husband?

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: Troth, he really will this day be the death of wretched me, through sheer disgust.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: to DEM ÆNETUS. Rise, wencher, be off home.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Yes, you areYes, you are: He says, "nullus sum," in the sense of "I'm undone;" but she chooses to take it as though he had meant "I am a worthless fellow," which meaning these words are capable of bearing.; don't, i' faith, gainsay it, you most vile of all men. Why, the cuckoo's still on his nestCuckoo's still on his nest: The cuckoo takes possession of the nests of other birds. and lays its eggs there. Artemona probably alludes to that fact, on seeing her husband under such a disgraceful circumstances.. Rise, wencher, be off home.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Woe to me!

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: You prophesy correctly. Rise, wencher, be off home.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Step a little this way then.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Rise, wencher, be off home.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: Now, prithee, wife----

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Do you remember now that I'm your wife? It was but just now, when you were heaping abuse upon me, that I wasn't your wife.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I'm utterly ruined.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Why, pray? Does the breath of your wife smell strong?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: It smells of myrrh.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Have you filched my mantle then to be giving to your harlot?

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: By the powers--what, did he promise that he would filch your mantle?

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Won't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: I was going to dissuade him, mother.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: to ARGYRIPPUS. A pretty son! To DEMÆNETUS. Is it proper for a father to teach these morals to his children? Are you ashamed of nothing?

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: I' faith, if there's nothing else, I'm ashamed of you, wife.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: With your hoary head, your wife is dragging you, you cuckoo, from dens of infamy.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: The dinner's cooking; mayn't I stop, only to take my dinner?

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: Faith, you'll dine to-day on a heavy mishap, as you deserve.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: rising. I shall repose but uncomfortably; my wife is taking me home condemned.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: I told you, father, not to devise ill against my mother.

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: to DEMÆNETUS. Do remember about the mantleAbout the mantle: This she says by way of farewell banter to the old fellow, whom she is too happy to get rid of., there's a dear.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: calls out to CLEÆRETA. Won't you order her to go away from here?

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: No, I'll go in, in preference. To ARGYRIPPUS. Follow me this way, my life.

sp.speaker: ARGYRIPPUS
sp.p: Yes, I follow.

sp.speaker: ARTEMONA
sp.p: to DEMÆNETUS. Be off home.

sp.speaker: PHILENIUM
sp.p: to DEMÆNETUS. Do give me a kiss, at least, before you go.

sp.speaker: DEMAENETUS
sp.p: to PHILENIUM. Go hang yourself. (Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: The COMEDIANS.
sp.p: If this old fellow, unknown to his wife, has been in any way indulging his own inclinations, he has been doing nothing new or wonderful, or otherwise than others are in the habit of doing. No one is there of a disposition so severe, or of a temper so firm, but that he will enjoy himself when he has any opportunity. Now if you wish to interpose in behalf of this old man, so that he be not punished, we think that it can be brought about if you give us loud applause.
